awd_titl_txt: Multi-Domain Identification of Functional Network Dynamics at the Neuronal Scale
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent technological advances in neural data acquisition from a large number of neurons across multiple brain regions have opened up a unique window of opportunity to gain insight into the complex dynamic interactions among neurons, within neuronal populations, and across brain regions at unprecedented spatiotemporal resolutions. In order to exploit these data, computationally efficient analysis techniques capable of simultaneously capturing the dynamicity, task-dependence, and statistical characteristics of the underlying functional networks are required. The research objective of this proposal is to develop a system identification methodology to extract functional network dynamics at the neuronal scale, and to apply it to large-scale recordings in order to probe and reveal the neuronal mechanisms that underlie behavior. 


The research approaches are to identify the temporal causal influences in neuronal ensembles in a robust and scalable fashion, capture abrupt changes in the covariance structure of the neuronal data, and extract the cross-frequency coupling of the network nodes with high resolution. This project addresses several outstanding challenges faced by existing methodologies, including loss of spectrotemporal resolution due to the use of sliding windows, lack of domain-specific models to capture the network dynamics, and ad hoc estimation procedures that result in highly biased network characteristics. By employing electrophysiology and two-photon calcium imaging data from the auditory systems of ferrets and mice, the proposed modeling and estimation framework will be used to investigate several fundamental questions pertaining to the functional organization of the networks involved in auditory processing. The project is expected to impact technology by providing signal processing solutions to be used in neural control systems. The research is also integrated with education and outreach activities including high school level workshops, undergraduate involvement, and course development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Growing evidence in recent years suggests that sophisticated brain function results from the emergence of dynamic and sparse functional networks underlying the brain activity. These networks are also task-dependent, which thereby allow the brain to rapidly adapt to abrupt changes in the environment resulting in robust and adaptive behavior. As such, computationally efficient analysis techniques capable of simultaneously capturing the dynamicity, task-dependence, and statistical characteristics of the underlying functional networks are required. The research objective of this project was to develop a system identification methodology to extract functional network dynamics at the neuronal scale, and to apply it to large-scale recordings in order to probe and reveal the neuronal mechanisms that underlie behavior.

The research approaches were to identify the temporal causal influences in neuronal ensembles in a robust and scalable fashion, capture abrupt changes in the covariance structure of the neuronal data, and extract the cross-frequency coupling of the network nodes with high resolution. This project addressed several outstanding challenges faced by existing methodologies, including loss of spectrotemporal resolution due to the use of sliding windows, lack of domain-specific models to capture the network dynamics, and ad hoc estimation procedures that result in highly biased network characteristics. By employing electrophysiology and two-photon calcium imaging data from the auditory systems of several animal models, the proposed modeling and estimation framework was used to investigate fundamental questions pertaining to the functional organization of the networks involved in auditory processing. The project could impact technology by providing signal processing solutions to be used in neural control systems. The research was also integrated with education and outreach activities including high school level workshops, undergraduate involvement, and course development.

The key outcomes of the project are as follows:

1) We designed an efficient greedy inference algorithm for time-domian identification of Granger causal influences in a neuronal network and applied it to two-photon recordings from the mice auditory cortex performing a pure tone discrimination task. Our results indicated that diverse functional network topologies emerge in the primary auditory cortex, pertaining to distinct behavioral outcomes (hit, miss, correct rejection, and false alarm) in the pure tone discrimination paradigm (See Image 1).

2) We designed an algorithm for inferring the semi-stationary spectra of latent neural covariates driving an ensemble of spiking neurons, and established theoretical guarantees on the bias-variance trade-off of our estimation algorithm. Application of our algorithm to experimentally-recorded neural data revealed the fine-scale frequency-domain interaction between excitatory and inhibitory neuronal population in the rat brain during sleep (See Image 2).

3) We developed an inference paradigm for extracting neuronal correlations from two-photon imaging data, without requiring intermediate spike deconvolution, which provided significant performance gains over existing methods as demonstrated by theoretical analysis, simulation studies, and real data applications (See Image 3).

4) We established theoretical guarantees on robust recovery of Granger causality via the LASSO in sparse multivariate autoregressive models. Granger causality is among the widely used data-driven approaches for causal analysis of time series data with applications in various areas including economics, molecular biology, and neuroscience. We addressed several outstanding challenges of this methodology by introducing a LASSO-based statistic and establishing fundamental limits for reliable identification of Granger causal influences using said statistic.

5) The PI is in the process of developing an advanced graduate course "Network-Level Neuronal Data Analysis", which will include topics based on results from this project.
